title: Even the Tories say failure to deliver on affordable homes was "embarrassment" after figures reveal 24-year low
text:
Gavin Barwell said his party's failure to provide enough affordable homes was an "embarrassment" (Photo: Getty) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The Tory housing minister today admitted the failure to build more affordable homes was an “embarrassment.” 
Gavin Barwell made the admission after being confronted by figures show the amount of affordable housing was at a 24-year low. 
“It is embarrassing, we want to stop that happening in the future,” he said. 
Mr Barwell was being questioned as the Government prepared to unveil on Tuesday its long-awaited housing white paper. 
The plans are expected to signal an end to the Tory crusade of mass home ownership by offering more help to those renting. 
Mr Barwell also rejected claims by Tory colleagues that the blueprint would allow for development on the Green Belt. The Government will unveil on Tuesday its long-awaited housing white paper (Photo: PA) 
“We are not going to weaken the protections. We have a clear manifesto commitment. there is no need to take huge tracts of land out of the green belt to solve the housing crisis,” he told ITV1’s Peston on Sunday. Read More Tories pledge to build 200,000 'starter' homes - but they'll cost up to £450,000 
Former Cabinet Minister Andrew Mitchell said allowing building on the Green Belt would be an “unforgivable act of vandalism.” 
Mr Mitchell was not assured by Mr Barwell’s claim that the development would only be allowed on Green Belt in “exceptional circumstances.” 
“The current circumstances, and this is what will concern Members of Parliament on both side, don’t work. 
“We’ve seen in Birmingham a monstrous plan put forward by the Labour council to build 6,000 homes on our treasured green belt and it’s been waved through by ministers,” Mr Mitchell said. 
Mr Barwell said the white paper would represent a “change of tone” from past Conservative housing policy. The plans are expected to signal an end to the Tory crusade of mass home ownership (Photo: PA) 
It will include proposals to amend planning rules to enable councils to plan for more build-to-rent-properties as well as measures to ensure more secure, longer term tenancies are available in the private rented sector. Read More Green light for first wave of garden villages set to create thousands of new homes across England 
There will also be measures to stop so-called “land-banking” by developers who obtain planning permission for a site but then do not build on it. 
“Absolutely we want to be a Government that helps people that are working hard to get onto the housing ladder but if you are going to have a country that works for everyone you have to have something to say to people that want to rent a home as well,” Mr Barwell said. 
“We want to see more housing built in this country of every kind. At the moment we are far too dependent on a small number of large developers building our homes. 
“We need to get more people involved in building homes and more different kinds of tenure - for outright ownership for shared ownership, for renting.” Like us on Facebook
